metadata.title: A simplistic approach to green future with eco-friendly luminescence carbon dots and their application to fluorescence nano-sensor ‘turn-off’ probe for selective sensing of copper ions

sections.text:
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
appears to be strategically balanced fluorescent nano-probes. In this work, purified lemon extract and L-arginine have been thermally coupled for the extremely acute detection of Cu 2+ in aqueous medium. The Cu 2+ ions may be captured by the amino groups on the surface of the nano-sensor to form cupric ammine complex resulting in quenched fluorescence via an inner filter effect. Our proposed nano-probe is N-doped carbon dots (NCDs) which are efficiently selective as fluorescent chemosensor due to enormous binding affinity towards Cu 2+ in a wide range of concentration (0.05-300 µM) within a few minutes.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Fluorescent carbon dots (CDs) have drawn eyes of extensive notice of many researchers owing to their unique and tunable optical properties with their size, low toxicity, good biocompatibility, excellent water solubility and ease of functionalization, enhance photostability. [1, 2] CDs, a new born member of carbonaceous nanomaterial were first reported in 2004 since the invention of Xu et al. during the separation of SWCNT by the arc-discharge method. They have considerably drawn a lot of attention for their interesting and unique advantages. [3-9] CDs exhibit numerous advantages compared to both fluorescent organic dyes and quantum dots, such as chemical stability, low photo bleaching, tunable luminescence emission, excellent biocompatibility [2] and blinking. [10] CDs (< 10 nm size) show excellent photoluminescence properties, low molecular weight and low toxicity, chemical inertness and a high degree of water solubility. [11] Recently, carbogenic dots have potential applications in the fields of bio-imaging [12-19] , energy conservation [20] , light-emitting devices [21] , sensing [22-31] , photocurrent response activity [32] , and photocatalysis. [33] Sun and co-workers described the prospective of passivated CDs for two-
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
photon fluorescence cells imaging [34] and used CDs for optical imaging in live mice. [12] CDs are mainly prepared by top-down and bottom-up approaches. [35, 36] In the top-down process, they are synthesized through electro-oxidation, [37] acid-assisted chemical oxidation, [38] laser ablation [39] using lamp black or candle soot, graphite as the precursor. These strategies require complicated, low yield, less selectivity and utmost synthesis conditions. [40] However, by using bottom-up approach CDs can be facilely prepared via carbonization of precursors molecule (such as amino acid, [41, 42] polyethylene glycol [43, 44] and polyethyleneimine [45] ) and solvothermal synthesis. [46] However, the synthesis of nitrogen doped carbon nano dots can be classified into three categories according to the nitrogen sources,(1) from small organic molecules like L-DOPA, ammonium citrate, DMF, urea, amino acids;(2) from inorganic molecules like NaNH2, aqueous ammonia(3) from natural sources such as strawberry juice [47] , grass [48] , bombyxmori silk. [49] NCDs have several applications of biosensing [50] , gas capture like CO2 [51] , oxygen reduction reaction [52] etc. In the present work, NCDs have been used to design a sensing system for selective detection of Cu 2+ ions. Copper (Cu 2+ ) is a key trace element to all living organisms as a dietary mineral because it is a vital component of the complex cytochrome c oxidase which is a respiratory enzyme. [53] At a level of about 1.4 to 2.1 mg/kg of body weight of copper remains in human body. [54] The safe limit of copper in drinking water to be 1.3 ppm (20 µM) has been set up by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). In the normal group the average concentration of copper in blood is 100–150 µg dL −1 (15.7–23.6 µM). Copper is an important trace dietary at very low amounts (less than 0.9 mg per day). However, short-time exposure to high levels of copper can be reason of gastrointestinal disturbance and long-time exposure can cause havoc damage to the kidneys and liver. For this reason, researchers have taken interest in developing novel nanoparticles low-cost, simple and green synthetic process for detection of heavy metal. Many modern techniques for copper screening like atomic fluorescence spectrometry, atomic emissions and absorption spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) demands expensive instrumentation, complicated sample preparation and time-consuming processes. Apart from these techniques, chemosensors offer a unique strategy for easy, inexpensive, rapid and reliable tracking of metal ions in biological and environmental samples. Chemosensor displays remarkable change in magnetic, optical or electrical signal when it gets attach with particular guest counterpart. Apart from the other sensors, luminescence chemosensor has numerous unique advantages due to their specificity,
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
sensitivity and rapid response time. [55-57] Herein, we report a facile one-step strategy to synthesize aqueous phase green luminescence NCDs from lemon juice which was used as carbon source and L-arginine which has nitrogen content. When Cu (II) was introduced to the aqueous solution of NCDs, the fluorescence of the NCDs solution was quenched (turn off) due to the electron transfer process. The amino group present at the surface of the NCDs can bind with Cu(II) ions to form cupric amine complex which results in great quenching of fluorescence via inner filter effect [58] . Based on the fluorescence change caused by Cu(II) ions, a sensing platform has been designed for specific and sensitive detection of Cu(II) ions, indicating unique applications in advanced chemistry.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text: Lemons were purchased from local market of Khargpur, India. L-arginine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Germany and used without any further purification. CuSO4·5H2O, HgO, FeSO4.7H2O, CaCl2.2H2O, CdCl2.H2O, AgNO3, BaCl2.2H2O, (CH3COO)2Zn2.H2O, (CH3COO)2Mg.4H2O, (CH3COO)2Pb.3H2O, and ethylenediamineteraacetic acid (EDTA) were purchased from Merck, Germany. All other chemicals used were of reagent grade.

sections.heading: Synthesis of NCDs
sections.text:
The N-doped CDs with mean size 3.5 nm were prepared from lemon juice and L-arginine through thermal coupling. Lemons are cut into small pieces and fresh juice was squeezed out. The juice obtained was then centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 10 min followed by filtration of the supernatant to get pulp free lemon juice. 7ml of purified extract of lemon juice and 0.21 g of Larginine were dissolved in 10mL of deionized water. The aqueous solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at a constant temperature of 200°C for 3h. A pale yellowish product was obtained which was cooled down to room temperature. The product was then dissolved in 15mL of deionized water and the particles were separated through filtration. To know the best optimum temperature we have synthesized the fluorescent NCDs at different temperatures 180°C, 200°C, 220°C and 240°C. In order to obtain high efficient fluorescence, we have prepared the NCDs upon varying the L-arginine amount 0.05g, 0.1g and 0.2g respectively. Obtained NCD solutions were confirmed by fluorescence emission spectra and stored at 4°C for further characterization. The synthesis procedure is illustrated in Scheme 1.
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T

sections.heading: Instrumentation
sections.text: The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum of the NCDs were obtained on a FTIR spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer, model-Spectrum-2, Singapore) in the range of 500-4000 cm -1 with resolution of 4 cm -1 and 16 scans. UV-visible absorption spectrum of the prepared NCDs in aqueous dispersion was measured using a UV Spectrometer (PerkinElmer, model-2 Singapore, Lambda35). Fluorescence experiments were measured on a Fluoromax_4C_1052D_4312_FM spectrofluorometer in aqueous solution. The fluorescence lifetime were measured on a timeresolved fluorescence spectrometer FL3-P-TCSPC (Horiba Jobin Jvon, France). The microstructure and morphology of the NCDs were analyzed using a high resolution transmission electron microscope HRTEM (JEOL, Japan operating voltage 200 kV with filament LaB6). The elemental composition and mapping of the prepared NCDs were investigated by energy dispersive X-ray study (EDX, INCA PentaFET x3, Oxford Instrument UK). The interlayer spacing and amorphous nature of the NCDs were recorded by X-ray Diffractometer (Panalytical High Resolution XRD-I, PW 3040/60). The zeta potential was obtained on a Zetasizer Nano ZS90 (Malvern Instruments, Manchester, U.K.) Raman measurements were performed using spectrometer (MODEL T64000 (Make JobinYvon Horiba, France). Argon-Krypton mixed ion gas laser (MODEL 2018 RM) was used as an excitation source. Thermoelectric cooled front illuminated 1024 256 CCD, MODEL Synpse TM (Make JobinYvon Horiba, France) was used as the detector. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured with a VG Scientific ESCALAB MK II spectrometer (UK) equipped with Mg Kα excitation source (1253.6 eV) and a five-channeltron detection system. Using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard 1 HNMR was recorded in on a Bruker, 600 MHz instrument at ambient temperature.

sections.heading: Characterization of the NCDs
sections.text:
The morphology and structure of prepared NCDs were confirmed by HRTEM micrograph. As shown in Figure 1a the NCDs are well dispersed without apparent aggregation and exhibited spherical shape. High-resolution TEM image (Figure 1b) of NCDs show lattice plane distances. NCDs have a narrow size distribution ranging from 2.5-4.5 nm with maximum population at about 3.5 nm (Figure 1c). The different functional groups and linkages on the NCDs were studied using FTIR spectroscopy (Figure 1d). In the spectrum, peak at 3559 cm −1 is assigned to
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
O−H or N−H stretching vibrations. Peaks at 2939, 1699, 1590, 1398 and 1360 cm −1 indicates the presence of–C–H, C=O, C=C,–COO− and C–O stretching respectively. Peaks observed at 1185 cm −1 and 768 cm −1 for C−N stretching vibrations and C−H bending vibrations respectively. The presence of polar groups in the NCDs makes them hydrophilic and improves water dispersibility. The elemental composition of the CDs was estimated from EDX data and the distribution was recorded by mapping (Figure 1e). The atomic force microscopy topography image of NCDs on silicon substrate was analysed. The AFM image (Figure 1f-g) shows that the NCDs were quasispherical and well-dispersed. The height profile of the NCDs obtained from AFM was also shown in Figure 1f. The mass and atomic ratios of carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and oxygen (O) of the NCDs were found to be 51.18: 5.11: 43.70 and 57.92: 4.96: 37.12, respectively. The sufficient amount of oxygen present in the C-dots supports its high water tolerance character. A wide peak centered around 27.2 o (002) in XRD pattern (Figure 2a) indicates highly disordered carbon atoms and graphene structures of the NCDs. [59, 60] The UV-visible absorption spectrum of the carbon nanodots shows a maximum absorption at 215 nm (Figure 2b). This is assigned to the n- π* electronic transition of the C=O moiety. The aqueous solution of synthesized NCDs with an abundance of 3.5 nm in size exhibit a broad emission spectra centered at 490 nm when excited at 340 nm which was shown in Figure 2c (inset shows green luminescence of the aqueous dispersion of the NCDs). The intensity of the photoluminescence (PL) peak depends on the number of particles excited at a specific wavelength that means for NCDs maximum population of the particles are excited at 340 nm. This indicates the fluorescent character of NCDs. The zeta potential was recorded to be -20.6 mV which can be assigned to the highly stable anionic CDs containing nitrogen groups on the surface. Even after three months of storage in air, their color remains unchanged without any precipitated or floating particles and they were still luminescent. This is may be due to tiny particle size and electrostatic repulsions between the CDs. Further, we analyzed the effect of dissolved oxygen in the NCDs solution to get reliable analysis result. Molecular oxygen is a well-known collisional quencher. 4mL of NCDs solution was purged by continuous flow of nitrogen gas for 25 min. The fluorescence signal (Figure S1 of the supporting information) of the NCDs solution was almost unchanged before and after the removal of dissolved oxygen by nitrogen purging. Therefore, from the dissolved oxygen test, we can say that the effect of
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
dissolved oxygen in the fluorescence activity can be neglected.The attempts to obtain the Raman spectra were unsuccessful because of the intense fluorescence property of the NCDs. [61, 62] The XPS spectrum of the as-prepared NCDs gives evidence for the nitrogen doping surface state shown in Figure 3a. The peaks at 531.6, 400.4 and 284.5 eV are attributed to O1s, N1s and C1s, respectively. The high resolution C1s spectrum shows four peaks at binding energies of 288.4, 286.5, 285.4 and 284.5 eV (Figure 3b), which are assigned to O-C=O (sp 2 ), C=O (sp 2 ), C–N (sp 3 ) and C–C (sp 3 ), respectively.[63, 64] The N1s peaks at 401.1 and 400.3 eV (Figure 3c) are associated with nitrogen in the states of N-H (sp 3 ) and (C)3-N (sp 3 ), respectively. [48] This indicates that the CDs are nitrogen-doped. The O1s signals at 533.5 and 531.6 eV (Figure 3d) can be assigned to oxygen in the form of C-O-C/C-OH and C=O, respectively. [48] The 1 H NMR spectrum (Figure S2 of the supporting information) of the nanodots were performed in D2O which reveals signals in different chemical environments. Peaks in the region 1.4–3 ppm for sp 3 C–H protons and amine groups of the protons, 3–4.5 ppm for the protons attached with carbonyl, hydroxyl and ether groups. [65] One of the unique properties of the NCDs is its fluorescent character. The shift in the PL peak from 440-470 nm was observed when excitation done ranging from 320-420 nm, shown in the excitation dependent PL spectra (Figure 4a). It is necessary to mention the reason of excitation dependent emission maxima and multi-exponential PL decay of CDs reported in most literature reports. Multiple species present (Figure S3 of the supporting information) in the system may interact with different energy traps which give rise to different absorption and emission from all of these species. Therefore for different excitation contribution of the species will be different for emission. Hence emission of the CDs will depend on excitation wavelength. Furthermore, as different species are present, they will choose different paths for PL decay. The interaction of energy traps with the excited states of different species will give rise to different excited state decay paths. Hence, the PL decay curve is supposed to be multi-exponential in nature which supports our experimental data (Figure S5 of the supporting information). Moreover, the excitation dependent luminescence feature of the CDs depends largely on the nature of their surface present which is discussed elsewhere. [65] Due to the presence of several functionalities on the surface of the CDs, series of emissive traps between π and π* of C–C may be obtained. On illumination at a specific excitation wavelength a surface energy trap of the CDs dominates the emission. Upon changing the excitation wavelength, other corresponding surface state emissive
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
traps become governing. This observation indicates that the mechanism of PL is controlled by both the surface defects and size effects. The temperature dependent fluorescence spectra of the NCDs dispersion (Figure 4b) shows increase in fluorescence signal as the temperature rises from 180°C to 200°C but the fluorescence (FL) intensity remains almost same at 220°C when excited at 340 nm. It also shows a decrease in FL intensity at 240°C. This is because of the complete carbonization of the NCDs. This assigned that illumination at a certain wavelength affects the FL intensity with temperature. Further we have studied the dependence of L-arginine amount on the FL intensity of the NCDs. Figure 4c shows by increasing the amount of L-arginine from 0.05 g to 0.2 g, keeping the volume of purified lemon extract as 7 mL in each case, the FL intensity gradually increases. The FL intensity shows highest value at 0.2 g L-arginine amount. Hence the optimized value for the preparation of NCDs was fixed at that ratio. It indicates that the FL emission intensity is primarily a function of the concentration of a certain fluorophore. From the Figure 4d it can also be shown that the FL intensity of the NCDs increases upon increasing the concentration. The salt effect of NCDs on the fluorescent properties has been measured. The FL intensity increases sharply with increasing KCL concentration, when the KCl concentration is lower than 0.7 mol/L (Figure S4 of the supporting information). However, the FL signal remains almost unchanged as the concentrations of the KCL rise from 0.7 to 2.0mol/L. This result indicates the fact that the aggregation of the NCDs can be effectively controlled by the ionic strengths of the salt and also individually separate NCDs under salt interference. The effect of the salt concentration on the FL intensity described that these CDs can be applicable to the extreme environmental conditions due to their strong luminescence property at higher salt concentration. The aqueous dispersion of the NCDs shows green luminescence on UV exposure at 365 nm. According to Lei Wang et.al, when carbon nanodots contain carboxyl groups and carbonyl groups on their surface, it will definitely lead to some common transient species in transient absorption spectroscopy. [66] From the recent findings on green luminescence carbon quantum dots via steady state photoluminescence analysis and HRTEM it was confirmed that green luminescence originated from disordered edge states. [67] Relying on the edge state of the carbon backbone which contains carbonyl groups and carboxyl groups, the generation of some special conformations can be accelerated by combination of carboxyl and carbonyl functionalities in the vicinity at the edge of the nano particles. The hybridization of the carbon backbone and these functionalities forms the common origin of green emission. [66]
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
Using quinine sulfate in 0.1M H2SO4 (literature value of quantum yield 0.54 at 340 nm) as a
reference, the quantum yield value for the NCDs was found to be 7.7% which is higher than the reported value of carbon quantum dots. [68] The quantum yield was calculated using the following equation QCD = QR× (ICD/IR) × (AR/ACD) × (η 2 CD/ η 2 R) (1) Where „Q‟ refers to the quantum yield, „I‟ represents the intensity of luminescent spectra, „A‟ is the absorbance at particular excited wavelength and „η‟ is the refractive index of the solvent used. The subscript „CD‟ refers to the carbon dots and „R‟ refers to the reference in this equation. The FL lifetime of the NCDs were measured to be 10.6 ns according to the FL decay profile (Figure S5 of the supporting information). The short lifetime of these NCDs indicate the radiative recombination of the excitons which give rise to FL. [43, 69]
In Figure 5 the plausible mechanism of the formation of NCDs was schematically interpreted. The mechanism for the preparation of NCDs from purified lemon extract and L-arginine includes carbonization of its constituents. Hydrothermal treatment of sucrose ends up in a quite complicated material structure and a well-defined strategy has not been reported yet. Hydrothermal carbonization of sucrose undergoes hydrolysis for the formation of fructose and glucose. Isomerization of glucose yields in fructose. The decomposition and dehydration of fructose or glucose yields in different organic acids like acetic, propionic, lactic, levulinic and formic acids, phenols, aldehydes, ketones and various soluble products like furfural compounds (for example: furfural,5-methyl furfural,5-hydroxymethyl furfural, etc). The hydronium ions generated from the above mentioned acids may act as catalyst in reaction stages of decomposition. It is necessary to mention that due to the existence of weak acid such as ascorbic acid and citric acid in lemon extract the decomposition and dehydration stages take place in controlled fashion. The intermolecular dehydration of these products with L-arginine give rise to several coupling compounds. The polymerization and condensation reaction ends up to form polymers. Aromatization and generation of aromatic clusters proceeds via cycloaddition reaction, aldol condensation, hydroxymethyl mediated furan resin condensation. In aqueous solution when the concentration of these cluster compounds reaches at critical supersaturation point then burst nucleation occurs and NCDs are formed. [70] FL sensing method of Cu 2+ ions
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
For sensitivity study, there should be an useful relationship between the quenched FL intensity and the Cu 2+ concentration that can be chosen for quantitative detection of Cu 2+ . Different concentration of Cu +2 solution ranging from 0-300 µM were investigated. In a typical run, aqueous dispersion of NCDs (200µL) was added into 10mL calculated amount of various concentration of Cu 2+ solution. The FL spectra were analyzed after reaction of 10 min at room temperature. Figure 6a shows the PL spectra of the NCDs at different concentration of Cu 2+ solution, revealing that FL intensity is sensitive to Cu +2 concentration. The FL intensity of the NCDs gradually decreases with the increase of Cu 2+ concentration when excited at 340 nm. The time-dependent FL spectra (Figure S6 of the supporting information) of the NCDs-Cu 2+ indicates that only 10 min required for the completion of the reaction between Cu 2+ and NCDs. The quenching mechanism of the NCDs can be realized more accurately by Stern-Volmer analysis. Quenching mechanism which is originated from collisional interaction between the quencher and the fluorophore is named as dynamic quenching. Dynamic quenching can be described by Stern-Volmer equation as follows [71] F0/F = τ0/ τ = 1+ kq τ0[Q] (2) where, F0 and F are the FL intensities in the absence and presence of the quencher, respectively. τ0 and τ are the FL lifetime in the absence and presence of the quencher respectively. kq is the rate constant of dynamic (collisional) quenching and [Q] is the quencher concentration in solution. Another type of quenching, i.e. static quenching occurs when a non-fluorescent complex formed between the fluorophore and the quencher. For this type of quenching the SternVolmer equation can be described as follows F0/F = 1+ KSV[Q] (3) where, KSV is the association constant. In static quenching the lifetime of the fluorophore is unperturbed and hence, τ0/ τ = 1. Figure 6b shows the dependence of F/F0 on the concentration of the Cu +2 ions over the range 0-300 µM. The plot does not fit a conventional linear Stern– Volmer equation which indicates both static and dynamic quenching processes occur in this sensor probe. [72]
Figure 6b inset shows the corresponding relationship between log F0/F versus
concentration of Cu 2+ ions. A good linearity (R 2 = 0.998) can be obtained in the concentration range 0 to 15 µM. The limit of detection (LOD) was calculated to be 0.047 µM using the three times standard deviation rule (LOD = 3σ/s, where σ is the standard deviation of the blank sample and s is the slope of the calibration curve). This detection limit (0.047 µM) is lower than the
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
other reported methods [73, 74] and comparable to previously reported other alternative methods [75- 77] . This limit also satisfactorily meets the safe limit of copper ions (~20 µM) in drinking water set by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The pH of the aqueous solution of the NCDs is another vital factor that can greatly affect the sensing probe of copper detection. The FL intensity of the NCDs in both the cases (in the absence and presence of Cu 2+ ions) are pH-dependent (Figure 6c). The NCDs (blue columns in Figure 6c) exhibit strong FL intensity in the pH range 4 to 6. However, the FL intensity becomes weak at the pH value greater than 9. In the presence of copper ions the quenched FL intensity can be observed over the pH range 2 -12 (red columns in Figure 6c). In strong acidic solution (pH value less than equal to 3) the amino groups present at the surface of the NCDs become protonated and are incapable of complexing with Cu 2+ to form cupric amine complex. In alkaline medium (pH value less than 7), the quenching activities does not meet to expectation, which may be the reason of partial hydrolysis of copper (Cu 2+ ) ions in the alkaline media hinders the complexation reaction between the amino groups of the NCDs and copper ions. This reveals that in weakly acidic media (pH value 4 to 6) have high quenching efficiencies and are suitable for sensing of copper (Cu 2+ ) ions. For selectivity study of this sensing system, the effect of the FL intensity in the presence of respective metal ions including Cd 2+ , Ba 2+ , Hg 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ag + , Ca 2+ , Li + , Mg 2+ , Pb 2+ and Zn 2+ under the same conditions were investigated (Figure 6d). In the spectra, no huge decrease in FL intensity was observed when the above metal ions were added in the aqueous dispersion of NCDs. In contrast, much lower FL was observed on addition of Cu 2+ in the NCDs dispersion. The selectivity of the Cu 2+ ions is due to the rapid chelation process with nitrogen and oxygen of the NCDs and higher thermodynamic affinity of the copper ions than other transition metal ions. [48] Evaluation of NCDs based Cu 2+ sensor in environmental samples The outstanding selectivity and sensitivity of the NCDs to Cu 2+ ions suggest that this nanosensor can be applied for detection of copper ions in environmental prospects. We applied a standard addition method to sense the concentration of Cu 2+ ions in river water. [58] To evaluate the performance of this sensor probe in practical application, we conducted the investigation using water samples obtained from Ganga river, West Bengal, India. Before the analysis, the river water sample was filtered through 0.20 µm membrane and centrifuged at 14000 rpm for 20 min. The obtained water samples were then spiked with different concentration of Cu 2+ ions and then
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
evaluate using the proposed mechanism. The FL intensity (excited at 340 nm) of the NCDs in the presence of river water containing different concentration of Cu 2+ ions dramatically decreases with increasing the concentration from 1 to 100µM as shown in Figure 7a. The relationship between F/F0 on the concentration of the Cu 2+ ions over the range 0-100µM was shown in Figure 7b. Inset (Figure 7b) shows the dependence of log F0/F versus concentration of Cu 2+ ions (from 0 to 15µM). In spite of the hindrance of various organics and minerals in the river water, this sensing probe can still perform for the selective detection of Cu 2+ ions. Establishment of the possible sensing mechanism As mentioned above the decrease of FL signal may be due to the formation of cupric amine complex at the surface of the NCDs. From the recent studies, the FL quenching (turn off) mechanism may be attributed to the inner filter effect, electron transfer process, non-radiative recombination pathway and ion binding interactions. [78] The PL spectra of the aqueous NCDs dispersion under various conditions (in absence and in the presence of 20 µM copper ions) have been measured. From the spectra, (Figure S7 of the supporting information) it can be seen that the NCDs give strong peak at 485 nm when excited at 340 nm. Whereas, on the addition of Cu 2+ , the PL peak shows a definite decrease in intensity indicating that the Cu 2+ ions can dramatically quench the FL of NCDs. Cu 2+ is a paramagnetic ion with d 9 system having one unfilled d shell and thus can quench the FL of the NCDs via energy or electron transfer. [79] It is believed that the chelation of Cu 2+ with the nitrogen and oxygen at the surface of the NCDs bring them close in proximity leading to the substantial decrease in FL signal. [80] When a strong Cu 2+ chelating agent, i.e. EDTA was added to the NCDs and Cu 2+ solution the FL signal was entirely restored which indicates that the inner filter effect associated with the cupric amine complex can be terminated with a competitive complexation reaction and as a result FL of the NCDs becomes reversible.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
The as-prepared FL based NCDs and the precursor both are eco-friendly and easy to prepare. It shows many promising advantages including good sensitivity, high selectivity, and fast detection of Cu 2+ ions and rarely interfered by other metal ions when excited at 340 nm in aqueous dispersion. The FL intensity of the NCDs versus Cu 2+ ions concentration shows good linearity from 0 to 15 µM with a detection limit of 0.047 µM. This result indicate that NCDs can be a
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
selective sensing probe of environmental application for detection of Cu 2+ ions in drinking water which has a safe limit of 20 µM set up by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). For the excellent luminescence property of these CDs they can be a promising candidate for further potential applications in bio-imaging, LEDs, light emitting devices as directed to green future.

metadata.abstractText: Zero-dimensional fluorescent nanoparticles having specificity as molecular probe appears to be strategically balanced fluorescent nano-probes. In this work, purified lemon extract and L-arginine have been thermally coupled for the extremely acute detection of Cu 2+ in aqueous medium. The Cu 2+ ions may be captured by the amino groups on the surface of the nano-sensor to form cupric ammine complex resulting in quenched fluorescence via an inner filter effect. Our proposed nano-probe is N-doped carbon dots (NCDs) which are efficiently selective as fluorescent chemosensor due to enormous binding affinity towards Cu 2+ in a wide range of concentration (0.05-300 μM) within a few minutes.
